Events.Sub-event: Howie's Battalion Advances to Relieve Bingham's Unit
Events.Sub-event_summary: On 17 July 1944, Major Thomas D. Howie's 3d Battalion, 116th Infantry advanced silently before dawn to relieve Major Bingham's isolated unit on the Martinville ridge amidst German fire and mist.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_45: On 17 July, the seventh day of attack, the 29th Division struck before dawn.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_46: Maj. Thomas D. Howie, commanding the 3d Battalion, 116th Infantry, led his men in a column of companies in a silent march toward Major Bingham's isolated unit.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_47: Suspicious Germans increased their artillery and mortar fire and played grazing machine gun fire across the slope of the Martinville ridge.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_48: Howie's men resisted the impulse to return this fire and crept forward through an early morning mist, still undetected.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_49: Several hours after daybreak, they reached Bingham's isolated force:

TOE.Personnel: Full strength battalion, specific numbers not detailed

Equipments.Supply: Ammunition and supplies carried by troops

Media.Description: Infantrymen Hit the Ground on a Street in St. Lo

Place.Place_Name: Martinville ridge, near St. Lô, France

Weather.Weather_text: Early morning mist, overcast with possible rain, average high 72°F low 55°F, incessant downpours in the region.

Events.Sub-event_summary: Major Howie agreed to advance his battalion alone into St. Lô but was killed by an enemy shell shortly after.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_50: The regimental commander, Colonel Dwyer, had hoped that the two battalions together would be able to enter the city, but Bingham's men were exhausted.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_51: Howie informed Dwyer by telephone that they were incapable of further effort.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_52: When Dwyer asked whether Howie could move his battalion alone to the eastern edge of town, Howie replied, "Will do."
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_53: Several minutes later an enemy shell killed him.

Media.Description: The flag draped body of Major Thomas Howie

Weather.Weather_text: Overcast, misty, average temperatures around 72°F high, 55°F low, with possible rain.

Events.Sub-event: Puntenny's Attempted Attack and German Counterattack
Events.Sub-event_summary: Captain Puntenny took command and attempted to attack St. Lô but was halted by heavy mortar fire. A German counterattack with tanks was repelled by American dive bombers and artillery.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_54: Taking command of Howie's battalion, Capt. William H. Puntenny tried to mount the attack on St. Lô along the Bérigny highway, but the Germans threw up such a heavy curtain of mortar fire that the men could not move.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_55: All through the day the German fire denied an advance.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_56: Late that afternoon a counterattack with tank support started from St. Lô to eliminate the Bingham-Puntenny force.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_57: Only the fortuitous presence of American dive bombers saved the day.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_58: While the planes strafed and bombed the German column, the division artillery placed a protective screen of fire about the American positions.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_60: Disorganized, the Germans withdrew their assault force, but now two American battalions were isolated.

Media.Description: Symbol of St. Lô - The flag-draped coffin of Major Howie

Weather.Weather_text: Overcast, suitable for dive bombing operations, average temperatures around 72°F high, 55°F low.

Events.Sub-event: Failed Efforts to Supply Isolated Battalions
Events.Sub-event_summary: Attempts to supply the isolated battalions with ammunition, food, and medical supplies failed due to clogged roads and enemy fire; light planes dropped blood plasma for 35 wounded men.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_61: All efforts of the 1st Battalion, 116th Infantry, to open a route to Bingham and Puntenny on 17 July and to bring forward ammunition, food, and medical supplies failed.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_62: Half-tracks and tank destroyers, escorted by quadruple .50-caliber machine guns, found the sunken roads about Martinville so clogged with debris, dead horses, and wrecked German vehicles that an advance under continuing enemy artillery fire was impossible.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_63: The 175th Infantry also attempted to reach the isolated men by attacking down the Bérigny highway, but the regiment sustained severe losses and made little advance.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_64: The only relief was that brought by light planes of the division artillery, which dropped sufficient blood plasma for 35 wounded men.

Weather.Weather_text: Overcast, with continuing enemy artillery fire possible in rainy conditions.

Events.Sub-event: Opening of Supply Route to Isolated Units
Events.Sub-event_summary: A carrying party reached the isolated units on the night of 17 July, and on 18 July a rifle company opened a supply route, evacuating wounded and capturing stray Germans.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_65: On the night of 17 July a carrying party of about forty men of the 1st Battalion, 116th Infantry, finally reached the isolated units.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_66: The next morning, 18 July, a rifle company--which had been reduced to 23 veterans but replenished with 85 replacements--opened a supply route to Bingham and Puntenny across the thousand-yard gap.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_67: Advancing in two columns along the axial hedgerows one field apart, maintaining visual contact between columns, and leaving four men in each field to hold the supply line open, the company met only light rifle fire.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_68: Supplies were brought forward and the wounded were evacuated.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_69: The few Germans, in small and disorganized groups, who blundered into the supply route during the day were either killed or captured.

TOE.Personnel: Rifle company: 23 veterans, 85 replacements; carrying party of 40 men

Equipments.Supply: Ammunition, food, medical supplies brought forward

Weather.Weather_text: Night and morning conditions, overcast, misty.

Events.Sub-event: Realization that Martinville Ridge Lost Importance
Events.Sub-event_summary: The Martinville ridge lost strategic importance due to German observation and fire; American forces on the ridge lacked strength for the final drive.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_70: By the time contact was firmly established with the two isolated battalions, the Martinville ridge had lost importance in the battle of St. Lô.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_71: The explanation had its basis in the condition that for seven long days had plagued the attacks along the ridge.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_72: In full view of the Germans south of the Bérigny highway, every American movement along the south face of the Martinville ridge had brought deadly fire.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_73: Though the two regiments on the ridge had constituted a threat to the town, they had been unable to make the threat good.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_74: Attempts to impress the troops with the fact that the German positions were worse than their own had not succeeded.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_75: "Tell them that Jerry is in a wedge," the division G-3 had ordered a liaison officer.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_76: "Jerry doesn't seem to realize it," had come the reply.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_78: So it seemed, for in spite of the wedge exerting pressure from the north--Hill 122--and from the east--the Martinville ridge--the Germans had obstinately refused to release their hold on the city.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_79: With the passage of time it had become a matter of increasing certainty that the forces on the ridge lacked the strength to make the final drive to the objective.

Media.Description: Symbol of St. Lô. The flag-draped coffin of Major Howie rests on the rubble-buried steps of Ste. Croix church.

Weather.Weather_text: Overcast with mist, contributing to defensive challenges.

Events.Sub-event_summary: General Gerhardt ordered the 115th Infantry to advance to the northeast outskirts of St. Lô, expending the battalion if necessary, reaching near the city by nightfall but exhausted.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_80: On the afternoon of 17 July, after the 35th Division had firmly established its control over Hill 122, General Gerhardt concluded that the 115th Infantry and not the regiments on the Martinville ridge really held the key to St. Lô.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_81: To insert the key, General Gerhardt had somehow to get the regiment to the gates of the city.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_82: He therefore directed Colonel Ordway to advance the 115th to the northeastern outskirts of St. Lô.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_83: The advance depended almost wholly upon the battalion in the regimental center.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_84: "Expend the whole battalion if necessary," General Gerhardt ordered, "but it's got to get there."
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_85: An hour later he repeated the same order.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_87: By nightfall of 17 July the troops of the entire 115th Infantry were near the northeastern fringe of the city, but getting there had brought them to the point of almost complete exhaustion.

Weather.Weather_text: Afternoon to night, overcast, rainy conditions in Normandy.

Events.Sub-event_summary: General Gerhardt changed the plan, ordering the Martinville ridge regiments to hold while the 115th made the main effort into St. Lô on 18 July.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_88: Convinced beyond doubt that the only feasible point of entry to St. Lô was the northeastern gate, General Gerhardt changed his week-long scheme of maneuver.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_89: For operations on 18 July, he ordered the two regiments on the left--those on the Martinville ridge--to hold in place while the 115th made the main effort into the city.

Events.Sub-event_summary: General Gerhardt discussed plans with General Baade and General Corlett, revealing tension and focus on taking St. Lô.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_91: Early on 18 July, General Gerhardt phoned to ask General Baade what he was planning to have the 35th Division do that day.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_92: General Baade replied that he would "probably sit tight."
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_93: As an afterthought he asked, "Are you going in?"
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_94: "I'm going to try," General Gerhardt answered.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_95: "In that case," General Baade said, "so will I."
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_96: "You can help on your left," General Gerhardt suggested.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_97: General Baade promised he would "look into it."
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_98: Three minutes later General Gerhardt was telling the corps commander that he thought the 35th Division should be ordered to attack to aid the 29th and not be allowed to attack "just because someone else [the 29th] is doing it."
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_99: General Corlett's reaction was sharp: "You had better just take on what I said in your order."
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_100: Apparently realizing Gerhardt's fatigue, he added, "Just take St. Lô and secure it."

Events.Sub-event_summary: German commanders discussed and requested permission to withdraw from St. Lô due to American advances and shortages.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_102: If these conversations revealed a tension among American commanders, those occurring among German officers disclosed even greater concern.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_103: Seventh Army had called Army Group B in the midafternoon of 17 July, and Hausser requested not only permission to withdraw in the St. Lô sector but also an answer by 1800 that day.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_104: There was some double talk about withdrawing to a line north of St. Lô, but this was not feasible in terms of the terrain.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_105: A withdrawal meant retirement to the heights just south of the city, though combat outposts could be retained north of St. Lô.

Events.Sub-event: Army Group Response to Withdrawal Request
Events.Sub-event_summary: Army Group B advised Seventh Army to take necessary measures for withdrawal without formal approval from higher command, to report it as enemy penetration.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_107: The request was rather surprising because under Hitler's standing order to hold fast, permission to withdraw was a prerogative of OKW.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_108: Yet more surprising was the army group reply to the Seventh Army.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_109: The operations officer of Army Group B stated that, after discussion, the staff had decided that forwarding Hausser's request to OB WEST for further transmittal to OKW was not practical.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_110: "You take whatever measures you think are necessary," the operations officer advised; "if you have to withdraw, go ahead; just report to us afterwards that the enemy penetrated your main line of resistance in several places and that you barely succeeded in re-establishing a new line to the rear."

Events.Sub-event_summary: American capture of Hill 122, troop shortages, and threats of encirclement prompted the German withdrawal; Rommel's accident added to the concern.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_112: Several reasons made a withdrawal necessary. American capture of Hill 122 and the attrition of the German troops in that sector exposed St. Lô from the north.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_113: The shortage of troops along the entire St. Lô front made it impossible for the II Parachute Corps to re-establish a defensive line north of the city.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_114: Underscoring the difficult, even hopeless, situation at St. Lô were the events that had occurred on the other side of the Vire: the 30th Division advance through Pont-Hébert to Rampan, the failure of the abortive Panzer Lehr counterattack on 15 July that did no more than delay the 30th Division advance, and the mistaken notion that U.S. troops had crossed the river at Rampan to infiltrate the rear of the 352d Division.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_115: All added up to the uncomfortable threat of American encirclement of St. Lô from the west.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_116: As though this was not bad enough, Rommel, the Army Group B commander, while driving forward to visit the front on the afternoon of 17 July, incurred a severe skull fracture in an automobile accident brought on by strafing from an Allied plane.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_117: That evening, when the news became known to the Germans, the OB WEST commander, Kluge, assumed command of Army Group B as well.

Events.Sub-event_summary: Kluge permitted the withdrawal after initial attempts to avert it; main German forces withdrew undetected on the night of 17 July, leaving combat outposts.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_118: By this time, Army Group B had passed Hausser's withdrawal request to OB WEST, which informed Jodl at OKW that troops were pulling back to hills north of St. Lô.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_119: Kluge tried to avert a complete withdrawal, but though he ordered Hausser to keep the Americans out of the city, he could find no reserves to reinforce the St. Lô sector.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_121: The 5th Parachute Division, which had arrived from Brittany several days earlier, was already committed to reinforce Panzer Lehr.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_122: The 275th Division, which was following the paratroopers, would not arrive in the St. Lô region for another day.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_123: Panzer Group West, which might have furnished troops, was expecting a strong British attack in the Caen area, and Kluge dared not disturb Eberbach's dispositions.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_124: Reluctantly, Kluge permitted Hausser to withdraw.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_126: Undetected by the Americans, the main forces retired that night leaving strong combat outposts north of St. Lô.

Events.Sub-event_summary: General Gerhardt replaced Colonel Ordway with Colonel Ednie; preparations for assault on 18 July were completed, cautious about not getting cut off.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_127: On the American side, General Gerhardt completed his preparations for assault on the morning of 18 July. Though the 115th Infantry had made the drive possible, Gerhardt replaced the regimental commander. "You did your best," Gerhardt told him. Colonel
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_128: Ednie, who had come from the 30th Division to understudy the assistant division commander, took his place. Ednie's mission was to open the northeast entrance to the city for the passage of General Cota's task force. Unaware of the German withdrawal, General Gerhardt was cautious. "We may go into St. Lô," he informed the corps commander, "but we don't want anyone to get cut off in there."

Media.Description: Infantrymen Hit the Ground on a Street in St. Lo

Events.Sub-event_summary: After artillery preparation, the 115th Infantry attacked, making good progress and hammering on the gate by noon; Task Force C was alerted.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_130: After an artillery preparation, the 115th Infantry attacked. Since Hill 122 was no longer a point of embarrassment, the regiment made good progress. At noon Colonel Ednie was hammering on the gate. "I believe this is the time to alert that Task Force," he advised General Gerhardt. The division commander no longer doubted. "Everything's shaping up now," he informed General Cota, "so I think you'd better get moving."

Weather.Weather_text: Morning to noon, overcast, allowing good progress.

Events.Sub-event: Task Force C Enters St. Lô
Events.Sub-event_summary: Task Force C, carrying Major Howie's body, entered St. Lô at 1800 on 18 July, seizing key points with scattered resistance; bridges intact.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_132: Forty minutes later General Gerhardt transmitted another order to General Cota. He wanted the body of Major Howie to accompany the first U.S. troops into town.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_134: The act was to be not only a gesture of honor and respect to the fallen but also a visible reminder to the members of the task force of all their comrades who had given their lives in a task not yet completed. The choice of Major Howie's body was particularly apt, for Howie, who had taken command of a battalion only three days before his death, represented the qualities of courage and sacrifice that had made the drive to the gates of St. Lô possible. The triumph belonged to the dead as well as to the living, and through Major Howie the fallen were to participate in the culmination of the effort.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_135: At 1500, 18 July, General Cota's Task Force C departed its assembly area near the division left boundary, crossed the division zone, and began to roll down the Isigny-St. Lô highway. Like a left halfback making a wide run around right end, the task force picked up its interference as it approached the line of scrimmage--the 1st Battalion, 115th Infantry, which was closest to the goal. Silencing an antitank gun just outside the town, passing through harassing artillery and scattered rifle fire, and breaking through a roadblock, the task force entered the northeast portion of St. Lô at 1800 of the eighth day of the battle. Quickly seizing a square near the cemetery and organizing it as a base of operations, Task Force C moved rapidly through the rubble-choked streets to points of importance. Small groups occupied key road junctions, squares, and bridges. One hour after the task force entered the town it was apparent that only scattered German resistance remained to be cleared. The bridges over the Vire were still intact.

Media.Description: Flag draped body of Major Howie in rubble

Events.Sub-event_summary: The 35th Division mopped up enemy, reached the Vire River, and moved to the northern edge of St. Lô; some troops entered the town despite boundary restrictions.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_137: About the time the 29th Division task force began its drive into St. Lô, the 35th Division completed its assignment.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_138: Colonel Byrne's 320th Infantry mopped up bypassed enemy in the center of the division zone, Colonel Emery's 137th Infantry reached the bank of the Vire River between the loop and the bend, and Colonel Miltonberger's 134th Infantry moved down the south slope of Hill 122 to the northern edge of St. Lô.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_139: Because the division boundary did not permit the 35th to enter into town, General Baade requested a boundary change.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_140: The XIX Corps G-3 first checked with General Gerhardt: "We have another division crying for part of St. Lô," he reported.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_141: "OK," General Gerhardt said, "let them go to it."
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_142: Despite General Gerhardt's largess, the corps commander was reluctant to condone the possibility of confusion and lack of control that might result from intermingling troops of the two divisions in the city.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_143: He decided not to shift the boundary, yet some 35th Division troops inevitably entered St. Lô and moved a short way into town.

Events.Sub-event: Reasons for the Fall of St. Lô
Events.Sub-event_summary: The weight of two divisions over eight days, capture of Hill 122, and Bingham's advance led to the fall; the scheme of maneuver was reversed.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_145: What had caused St. Lô to fall was the weight of two divisions pressing forward relentlessly for eight days. But if specific events have direct causal relation, two were mainly responsible. The capture of Hill 122 was the more obvious, for its seizure the day before the fall of St. Lô had deprived the Germans of a vital point in their line of defense. The other event was of more subtle significance. At the same time that the 35th Division was securing a hold on Hill 122, the 29th Division was penetrating the enemy defensive line across the Martinville ridge by means of Major Bingham's accidental advance of 1,000 yards. Although temporarily encircled and isolated, Bingham's battalion, less than 1,000 yards from St. Lô, presented a serious menace to the defenders--"an enemy battalion behind our lines."
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_147: Major Howie's relief force had strengthened the threat. Although the 29th Division troops on the Martinville ridge did not have the power to take the city, their positions constituted a containment force, a base or anchor for the coup de grace delivered by Task Force C. The original scheme of maneuver had thus been reversed. The intended maneuver force, the 116th and 175th Regiments, had become the base, while the 115th Infantry, earlier designated the holding force, had become, with Task Force C, the assault element.

Weather.Weather_text: General conditions during the battle, overcast and rainy.

Events.Sub-event_summary: Reflection on whether attacking Hill 122 earlier could have expedited the capture by shielding the advance from German fire.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_148: If speed was a fundamental requirement of General Gerhardt's mission, the question of whether the corps attack had been the most expeditious manner of securing St. Lô remained a lingering doubt. Other U.S. units advancing with the same slow rate of speed in the hedgerow country obscured the possibility that the corps might have secured its objective more rapidly had it attacked Hill 122 at the same time that the V Corps had attacked Hill 192. Had the Americans controlled Hill 122, the 29th Division would have been able to make its thrust to St. Lô across the north slope of the Martinville ridge and have been shielded from the German fire south of the Bérigny road.

Media.Description: Symbol of St. Lô. The flag-draped coffin of Major Howie rests on the rubble-buried steps of Ste. Croix church.

Events.Sub-event_summary: General Gerhardt prepared a message announcing the capture, but NBC broadcast it first via radio.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_149: General Gerhardt had a formal message prepared to announce the capture of St. Lô. At 1830, half an hour after Task Force C entered the streets of the town, he confidentially released the message to his special services officer in time to make that evening's edition of the division mimeographed newspaper. "I have the honor," the message read, "to report to the Corps Commander . . .," but before General Gerhardt could proclaim the achievement, General Corlett telephoned to inform him that he had already heard the news on a radio broadcast. "NBC beat you to it," General Corlett announced.

Events.Sub-event_summary: German artillery hit the town; the 352d Division counterattacked but was too weak to expel the Americans.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_151: Although St. Lô was taken, it was by no means safe. German artillery smashed into the town. Surprised and embarrassed by the speed with which the Americans had taken the city, Hausser ordered Meindl to have the 352d Division retake the town, but refused Meindl's request for part of the 275th Division, which had just arrived from Brittany and was in the Seventh Army reserve behind Panzer Lehr. The 352d Division, which had tried to hold the Vire bridges by fighting in St. Lô with too few men, mounted a counterattack but was too weak to expel the Americans. Hausser and Meindl both later blamed an announcement by the Wehrmacht on the afternoon of 18 July of the withdrawal as the stimulus that had caused the final American assault. Actually, however, they had been unable to secure additional troops and they had feared that U.S. forces west of the Vire would outflank St Lô from the west; both commanders in reality had been forced by American pressure to pull the II Parachute Corps back.

Events.Sub-event: Cavalry Reconnaissance and Confirmation of German Position
Events.Sub-event_summary: The 113th Cavalry Group passed through St. Lô but encountered heavy fire south of the city, confirming Germans on high ground less than a mile south; counterattack confirmed.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_153: To maintain contact and determine the extent of the withdrawal, General Corlett instructed the 113th Cavalry Group to pass through the city. The cavalry received such a volume of antitank, mortar, and artillery fire 500 yards south of St. Lô that it became evident at once that the Germans had retired only to the high ground less than a mile to the south. The 352d Division counterattack launched that evening confirmed the fact that the enemy had not gone far.

Events.Sub-event_summary: XIX Corps completed its task on 19 July with clearing the city and no active enemy in the sector.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_155: The XIX Corps completed its task on the morning of 19 July. The 29th Division finished clearing the city, and the 35th Division reported no active enemy troops in its sector.

Events.Sub-event_summary: The 35th Division lost over 2,000 men, the 29th over 3,000; on 19 July, the 35th relieved the 29th across the corps front.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_157: In capturing St. Lô the divisions had sustained the high losses that had become typical of the battle of the hedgerows. The 35th Division lost over 2,000 men; the 29th Division suffered over 3,000 casualties. On 19 July, in compliance with corps instructions, the 35th Division relieved the 29th, and General Baade deployed his troops across the entire corps front from the Vire River east to the Couvains-Calvaire road.

Weather.Weather_text: General battle period, bad weather with downpours.

Events.Sub-event_summary: Major Howie's body became a symbol of sacrifice, placed before Ste. Croix church; St. Lô itself became a memorial to the fallen in the hedgerows.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_158: By the time the men of the 29th Division marched out of St. Lô on 20 July, the body of Major Howie had become a symbol. Task Force C had carried the flag-draped corpse as a battle standard into town on a jeep.
Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_160: Placed on a pile of rubble before the rather plain Romanesque church of Ste. Croix and surrounded by empty, gaping houses, the body had become a shrine, a universal symbol of sacrifice. When the men of the division removed the body and departed the town, the symbol remained in St. Lô. St. Lô itself, disfigured and lifeless, had become a memorial to all who had suffered and died in the battle of the hedgerows.

Media.Description: Symbol of St. Lô. The flag-draped coffin of Major Howie rests on the rubble-buried steps of Ste. Croix church.

Place.Place_Name: Ste. Croix church, St. Lô, France

Footnotes.Footnote_Text: A legend had also been born. In 1953 a roadside sign in St. Lô read: ". . . This martyred city was liberated the 26th [ sic. ] of July 1944 by Major Howie, killed at the head of his troops. . . ."
